title: A Note on the “Gods” of the Subtle Level
summary:
This section disentangles visionary potency from ultimate reality. The author affirms that subtle-level encounters can feel more real than space-time, yet insists they are not final. Deities met precisely as tradition depicts them are read as either collective thoughtforms or presences donning those culturally authored vestments. In both cases, the decisive agent is the collective psyche, whose centuries of prayer, fear, devotion, and imagination sculpt living templates that the psyche—and sometimes spirit—inhabits. Here, the scriptures do not perfectly capture a preexistent celestial form; rather, their descriptions become liturgical scripts that billions rehearse until the imprint attains autonomous vibrancy and durability, even after its parent culture fades.

The author refuses to trivialize such forms. Thoughtforms, including the secular gods of greed and power, are consequential currents—psychic weather systems that organize experience, organize history, and erupt as commanding presences in sessions. Their magnitude, however, does not guarantee ultimacy. From a deeper vantage, these arresting agents are masks of the real, not the real itself. Religious depictions of gods, including the monotheistic God, are therefore understood as cultural approximations: luminous, efficacious, and partial. As practice descends or ascends beyond the subtle, the imaginal wardrobe loosens. Icons, myths, and inherited beliefs fall away like garments from actors; what remains is Nature standing bare—an invitation to behold afresh without the mediation of inherited images.

This apophatic turn, consonant with The Cloud of Unknowing, recommends unlearning as spiritual method. To glimpse the Divine as it is, one relinquishes what one knows about it, including cherished archetypes. The argument is not iconoclastic disdain but disciplined reverence: forms are to be honored as thresholds and released as absolutes. The section thus refines psychedelic epistemology with theological humility, distinguishing phenomenological intensity from ontological depth and counseling the courage to let even the most radiant forms perish into the formless.

In the book’s arc, this chapter marks the pivot from archetypal fidelity to nonconceptual seeing, preparing the reader for the movement from the subtle’s shimmering multiplicity toward the ground of diamond clarity.
notes: Situates deity encounters within a graduated ontology; suggests cross-reference to discussions of tulpas/egregores and to later chapters on causal/nondual realization.
